Expectation1: Support each other emotionally during tough times
Situation1: One sibling has just received some very difficult news and is deeply distressed by it.
Situation2: They skim a recent pharmacy newsletter while on break to see what new drugs have been released.
Story: I sat in the cramped break room, the latest pharmacy newsletter open on my phone, trying to absorb the updates on new drug releases. My mind was half on the article, half on the clock, knowing I had only a few minutes before my shift resumed. Suddenly, my phone buzzed with a message from my stepbrother: “Can you call? I really need you.” He’d just gotten some terrible news about our dad’s health, and I could almost hear the panic in his words. As a step-sibling, I knew he expected me to be there, to listen, to help him process the shock. But as a pharmacist, I was expected to stay sharp, keep up with the latest medications, and return to the counter ready to answer questions from patients and doctors alike. My heart twisted as I stared at the phone, torn between the urge to call him immediately and the professional responsibility pressing on me. The weight of both roles pressed down, each demanding my full attention, and I sat frozen, wrestling with which expectation I would have to let down.
